div.p: When you join up you do basic law input and stuff and it’s very much in the classroom, then, it’s changed a lot now but it was learning
the law verbatim, learning your arrest powers verbatim and then you’d go into role plays and go out and try and put these things
into practice and you learn basic theft stuff from stealing and basic drugs offences, basic sexual offences and basic motoring offences
and stuff like that. You would spend I think it was 16 weeks at training school which was down near Yeovil and you'd come back and then you had
4 weeks with an experienced officer where you were sort of out with experienced officers and they’d show you how to do the job properly
and what have you and I went through that process but my aim having joined the police service from a very early stage was that I wanted
to be a detective, I wanted to be on the drug squad and do all the Gucci things like Jack Regan and all this stuff that we’d sort of grown up with
and that was my aim and fortunately enough for me I had some good jobs when I was in uniform and got myself noticed by the CID
and got myself what you call to do a CID attachment first which is where you go onto the CID, it’s like slave labour really,
you’re there for 4 or 5 months dealing with all the rubbish jobs that come into the office and they test your mettle to see if you’re good,
your investigative skills and all the rest of it and you’re then put forward for your CID training. Being away 16 weeks I had a young family then,
coming home every weekend and having tons of homework to do when I could have spent more time with my family doing family things,
my daughters were then 5 and 3 I think at that stage, and I was trying to concentrate on the training because it was important
to get through the first 2 years of police service because if you don’t get through the probation period you’re out on your ear so I wanted
to put everything into it and focus on that to get through it so it did impact on family life and it did throughout my service after that really
because it’s one of those jobs that do...
